Former West Ham manager Harry Redknapp has revealed the extreme and bizarre methods he would use to keep star striker Paolo Di Canio "sweet". 
The Irons signed the Italian from Sheffield Wednesday in January 1999, just three months after he received an 11 game ban for pushing over referee Paul Alcock. 
Speaking to Betsafe , Redknapp opens up on how he convinced chairman at the time Terry Brown to sign the striker. 
And he admits that he had been watching the player since his Celtic days. Di Canio left Upton Park a legend (Photo: Getty Images Europe) 
But Redknapp also revealed that he used some rather bizarre tactics to keep Di Canio happy. 
"He was high maintenance but he was a genius, he was a fantastic player," said Redknapp. Di Canio was high maintenance, says Redknapp (Photo: The People) 
"I used to make sure I put him on a team in training where nobody would kick him because otherwise it would all blow up. He was volatile. 
"He used to kick one wide and I'd used to say it was a goal. It's Paolo. Got to keep him sweet for Saturday." poll loading Who is football's biggest bad boy? 1000+ VOTES SO FAR
